user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_irq_set_enable:
```c
static void metal_linux_irq_set_enable(struct metal_irq_controller *irq_cntr,
				       int irq, unsigned int state)
{
	int offset, ret;

	if (irq < irq_cntr->irq_base ||
	    irq >= irq_cntr->irq_base + irq_cntr->irq_num) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s: invalid irq %d\n",
			  __func__, irq);
		return;
	}
	offset = irq - linux_irq_cntr.irq_base;
	metal_mutex_acquire(&irq_lock);
	if (state == METAL_IRQ_ENABLE)
		metal_bitmap_set_bit(irqs_enabled, offset);
	else
		metal_bitmap_clear_bit(irqs_enabled, offset);
	metal_mutex_release(&irq_lock);
	/* Notify IRQ thread that IRQ state has changed */
	ret = metal_linux_irq_notify();
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR,
			  "%s: failed to notify set %d enable\n",
			  __func__, irq);
	}
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_irq_set_enable:
struct metal_irq_controller {
	int irq_base; /**< Start of IRQ number of the range managed by
		 	* the IRQ controller
		 	*/
	int irq_num; /**< Number of IRQs managed by the IRQ controller */
	void *arg; /**< Argument to pass to interrupt controller function */
	metal_irq_set_enable irq_set_enable; /**< function to set IRQ enable */
	metal_cntr_irq_register irq_register; /**< function to register IRQ
						* handler
						*/
	struct metal_list node; /**< list node */
	struct metal_irq *irqs; /**< Array of IRQs managed by the controller */
}
...
static METAL_IRQ_CONTROLLER_DECLARE(linux_irq_cntr,
				    0, MAX_IRQS,
				    NULL,
				    metal_linux_irq_set_enable, NULL,
				    irqs)
...
static metal_mutex_t irq_lock
...
static unsigned long
irqs_enabled[metal_div_round_up(MAX_IRQS, METAL_BITS_PER_ULONG)]
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
struct metal_irq_controller {
	int irq_base; /**< Start of IRQ number of the range managed by
			* the IRQ controller
		*/
	int irq_num; /**< Number of IRQs managed by the IRQ controller */
	void *arg; /**< Argument to pass to interrupt controller function */
	metal_irq_set_enable irq_set_enable; /**< function to set IRQ enable */
	metal_cntr_irq_register irq_register; /**< function to register IRQ
			* handler
		*/
	struct metal_list node; /**< list node */
	struct metal_irq *irqs; /**< Array of IRQs managed by the controller */
}

static void metal_linux_irq_set_enable(struct metal_irq_controller *irq_cntr,
				       int irq, unsigned int state)

static METAL_IRQ_CONTROLLER_DECLARE(linux_irq_cntr,
				    0, MAX_IRQS,
				    NULL,
				    metal_linux_irq_set_enable, NULL,
				    irirs)
explanation: Other pointer-like uses in the function and related code were not selected because they clearly require a writable (non-const) pointee or are not relevant to Rule 8.13: - The bitmap operations (metal_bitmap_set_bit/metal_bitmap_clear_bit) operate on irqs_enabled and modify its contents, so the bitmap pointer cannot be const. - The mutex operations (metal_mutex_acquire/metal_mutex_release with &irq_lock) modify the mutex state; the mutex pointer must be non-const. - irqs_enabled is an array that is written by the bitmap functions, so its storage cannot be const. - Calls such as metal_linux_irq_notify and metal_log do not introduce new object pointers that could be const-qualified in this context. - Function-pointer members in the struct (irq_set_enable, irq_register) are function pointers (not pointers to object data) and const-qualification of the pointee is not applicable in the same way as object pointers for this rule. These cases therefore do not need investigation under Rule 8.13.
